Award.AwardTitle: CC*IIE Engineer: A Software-Defined Campus Network for Big-Data Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Scientific researchers on university campuses create, analyze, visualize, and share large and diverse datasets from experimental devices like brain scanners, particle colliders, and genome sequencers. However, these "big data" applications place strain on traditional campus networks, due to rapidly increasing volumes of data, the need for either predictably low latency (to adapt experiments in real time) or high throughput (to transfer large data sets between locations), and sophisticated access-control policies (to protect the privacy of human subjects). To enable the next wave of scientific advances, university campuses must find effective ways to meet these challenging demands, at reasonable cost. The emerging technology of Software-Defined Networking (SDN) lowers the barrier to innovation in network management, and can substantially reduce cost through (i) inexpensive commodity network switches, (ii) greater automation of network configuration, and (iii) novel network-management applications that optimize bandwidth usage. Yet, existing innovation in SDN focuses primarily on the needs of commercial cloud providers, rather than the unique requirements of university campuses and scientific researchers. Princeton University is creating a software-defined campus network that can enable the next generation of data-driven scientific research. The initiative brings together big-data science researchers, computer scientists who are experts in SDN, and the campus Office of Information Technology. Princeton is deploying an open-source SDN platform for monitoring and configuring the network, conducting trials of new ways to support big-data applications, and bridging with the larger community, on and off campus, to support the sharing of scientific data, SDN software, and operational experiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major scientific advances increasingly come from sophisticated analysis of large data sets, such as real-time brain imagery, Large Hadron Collider data, and human genome sequences.  These datasets may be collected locally from experiments running on the university campus or retrieved from other sites, including remote collaborators or large public facilities.  University campuses must find effective ways to meet the challenging demands of “big­ data” science applications on their networks, at reasonable cost. The emerging technology of Software­-Defined Networking (SDN) lowers the barrier to innovation in network management, and can substantially reduce cost through (i) inexpensive commodity network switches and middleboxes, (ii) greater automation of network configuration, and (iii) novel control applications that allow the campus to make more effective use of limited network bandwidth. Yet, existing work on SDN focuses primarily on the needs of commercial providers, rather than the unique requirements of university campuses and scientific researchers.

At Princeton University, we have embarked on a major initiative to create a software­-defined campus network infrastructure that can enable the next generation of data­-driven scientific research. We assembled a diverse group that includes: (i) big ­data sciences researchers in neuroscience, physics, geosciences, and genomics, (ii) software-­defined networking researchers in computer science who are designing and deploying new SDN technologies that enable the flexible management of networking resources, and (iii) the campus Office of Information Technology (OIT) that created a data center near campus.  Together, this group identified compelling big data applications, such as real-time neuroscience experiments that change the stimulus given to a human subject in response to analysis of brain scans from an fMRI machine.  During the course of the project, we surveyed campus researchers to identify their unique requirements, designed and deployed a monitoring infrastructure for rapid detection and diagnosis of performance problems, made key upgrades to the campus network infrastructure, and prepared the campus network for the transition to an SDN-enabled infrastructure.


For example, to better support big-data applications, we deployed several Data Transfer Nodes (DTNs) that use the Globus service to exchange large amounts of scientific data efficiently, and also added support for monitoring to track DTN activity and quickly identify performance problems.  To avoid a major performance bottleneck on campus, we deployed a solution for allowing large volumes of scientific data to selectively bypass our Intrusion Prevention System (IPS), to reduce cost and improve performance without compromising security.  To prepare for our transition to SDN, we conducted extensive testing of commercial SDN switches that support the OpenFlow protocol, and also outlined plans for a programmable campus border router.  To support further research and experimentation in SDN for campus networks, we planned for the deployment of programmable switches and network interface cards that support the emerging P4 language. Throughout these efforts, we have shared software, experiences, and white papers with the larger university community including Internet2.  Together, these and other initiatives have greatly improved the Princeton campus network’s ability to support big-data science research while helping prepare Princeton and other campuses for an SDN-enabled future.
